articles.headline: Tearful Obama Outlines Steps to Curb Gun Deaths
articles.snippet: “Every time I think about those kids, it gets me mad,” the president said, discussing the victims of the Sandy Hook Elementary School shooting.
articles.abstract: “Every time I think about those kids, it gets me mad,” the president said, discussing the victims of the Sandy Hook Elementary School shooting.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As tears streamed down his face, President Obama on Tuesday condemned the gun violence that has reached across the United States and vowed to curb the bloodshed with or without Congress.
articles.byline: By Eric Lichtblau and Michael D. Shear

articles.headline: Racial Identity, and Its Hostilities, Are on the Rise in American Politics
articles.snippet: In an important shift, racial, ethnic and cultural identity is recovering its role as a main driver of political choice.
articles.abstract: In an important shift, racial, ethnic and cultural identity is recovering its role as a main driver of political choice.
articles.lead_paragraph: Why do working-class Americans vote as they do?

articles.headline: Centerview Benefits From Wall St.’s Pivot to Smaller Banks
articles.snippet: The personal touch is helping boutique shops compete in the market for advice on deals and strategy, but the founders of Centerview Partners hope to transcend personalities.
articles.abstract: The personal touch is helping boutique shops compete in the market for advice on deals and strategy, but the founders of Centerview Partners hope to transcend personalities.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a pink marble skyscraper opposite the Museum of Modern Art, 20 summer analysts at the investment bank Centerview Partners listened while Robert E. Rubin, the former Treasury secretary, opined on the state of the world.

articles.headline: Downfall of André Esteves Stands Out in Brazil Scandal
articles.snippet: The arrest of Mr. Esteves, who once epitomized Brazil’s global ambitions, in a corruption investigation has rattled the financial community.
articles.abstract: The arrest of Mr. Esteves, who once epitomized Brazil’s global ambitions, in a corruption investigation has rattled the financial community.
articles.lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — André Esteves is not the only rich and powerful Brazilian to be swept up in a corruption investigation that has rocked the country.

articles.headline: Saudi-Iran Feud Poses Threat to Iraq’s Effort to Combat ISIS
articles.snippet: As Iraq faces the challenge of routing ISIS, it is confronted with a conflict between Iran and Saudi Arabia that threatens to inflame sectarian tensions.
articles.abstract: As Iraq faces the challenge of routing ISIS, it is confronted with a conflict between Iran and Saudi Arabia that threatens to inflame sectarian tensions.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — The fighting has finally stopped in Ramadi, a major city in the Sunni heartland. The Islamic State has been ousted, and the Iraqi flag is flying once again.
articles.byline: By Ben Hubbard, Anne Barnard and Somini Sengupta

articles.headline: Protesters in Oregon Seek to End Policy That Shaped West
articles.snippet: An armed group that is occupying a wildlife reserve in Oregon has called for Washington to hand control of federal lands to ranchers and local governments.
articles.abstract: An armed group that is occupying a wildlife reserve in Oregon has called for Washington to hand control of federal lands to ranchers and local governments.
articles.lead_paragraph: BURNS, Ore. — They used to call it Bundyville, a dot of the arid Wild West where in 1916, a Mormon pioneer named Abraham Bundy staked out a homestead in a sea of northern Arizona sagebrush. Settlers caught rainwater in tanks and grazed their livestock across public land that had yet to be brought under government control.
articles.byline: By Kirk Johnson and Jack Healy

articles.headline: North Korea Says It Has Detonated Its First Hydrogen Bomb
articles.snippet: The claim, if true, would drastically escalate the nuclear challenge from one of the world’s most isolated and dangerous states.
articles.abstract: The claim, if true, would drastically escalate the nuclear challenge from one of the world’s most isolated and dangerous states.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — North Korea declared on Tuesday that it had detonated its first hydrogen bomb.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Choe Sang-Hun

articles.headline: On Display at CES, Tech Ideas in Their Awkward Adolescence
articles.snippet: Plenty of groundbreaking technologies are in the works, but in the meantime, expect to be bombarded with early, clumsy versions of tomorrow’s tech.
articles.abstract: Plenty of groundbreaking technologies are in the works, but in the meantime, expect to be bombarded with early, clumsy versions of tomorrow’s tech.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s a cliché for journalists to whine about International CES, the annual consumer electronics show that brings gadget-hounds and billionaires like a nerdy plague upon Las Vegas this week. As many have complained — yours truly included — CES long ago devolved into a noisy parade of puffed-up announcements that usually amount to nothing.

articles.headline: In Iowa, Ted Cruz Savors Lead Role
articles.snippet: The Texas senator’s campaign is building on an energized, growing coalition and a splintered opposition. Still, there’s the Trump factor to be considered.
articles.abstract: The Texas senator’s campaign is building on an energized, growing coalition and a splintered opposition. Still, there’s the Trump factor to be considered.
articles.lead_paragraph: ONAWA, Iowa — Senator Ted Cruz of Texas insists he does not want to be seen as the front-runner in the Iowa caucuses. “The only way I know how to run is as an underdog,” he said here after a speech on Tuesday, waving off any Joe Namath-style guarantee of victory.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin and Matt Flegenheimer

articles.headline: Security Council Condemns Nuclear Test by North Korea
articles.snippet: The White House press secretary and South Korean analysts say that the estimated yield, or energy, from the explosion appeared to be too small for a hydrogen bomb.
articles.abstract: The White House press secretary and South Korean analysts say that the estimated yield, or energy, from the explosion appeared to be too small for a hydrogen bomb.
articles.lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — The United Nations Security Council condemned North Korea for its nuclear test on Wednesday, but there was no evidence yet that the North’s most powerful backer, China, was willing to stiffen sanctions in a way that could push the unpredictable country to the point of collapse or slow its nuclear progress.
articles.byline: By Somini Sengupta, David E. Sanger and Choe Sang-Hun

articles.headline: North Korea’s Hydrogen Bomb Claim Strains Ties With China
articles.snippet: North Korea’s announcement that it had completed a test of the weapon infuriated China, which had recently sought to forge closer ties with its reclusive neighbor.
articles.abstract: North Korea’s announcement that it had completed a test of the weapon infuriated China, which had recently sought to forge closer ties with its reclusive neighbor.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — North Korea’s test of a nuclear bomb on Wednesday seemed aimed at antagonizing a familiar adversary, the United States. The army spoke of the need to ward off “imperialist aggressors,” and a television commentator warned that foreigners were intent on destroying the country’s way of life.
